abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Earthquake Recovery
            Project for Colombia was highly satisfactory, the
            sustainability was highly likely, the institutional
            development impact was substantial, and the Bank and
            borrower performance were both satisfactory. The lessons
            learned indicated that after an emergency of this magnitude,
            the local government lacked the resources to cope on their
            own and received little assistance for the first week. Areas
            affected by disasters need immediate assistance from both,
            national governments and international agencies. The
            increased empowerment of beneficiaries enhanced their
            understanding of their rights, responsibilities, and their
            capacity to work together to identify priorities and create
            consensus. Maintaining low overhead costs in the
            Reconstruction Fund for the Coffee Region (FOREC) was
            important. Several of the Non-Governmental Organizations
            lacked sufficient procurement and engineering capacity. The
            reconstruction program was slow to address the needs of rent
            households. The use of "vitrinas inmobiliarias"
            was an innovative and effective way of providing large
            numbers of new housing units by balancing supply and demand.
            The reconstruction of Barrio Brasilia, in the City of
            Armenia, which was devastated by the earthquake, provided
            special lessons in terms of social organization of the
            community and the use of legal instruments for land titling.

5086500.trustfund:
TF039147-COLOMBIA - EARTHQUAKE
            RECONSTRUCTION PROJECT,TF037872-COLOMBIA - EARTHQUAKE EMERGENCY
            RECOVERY LOAN
5086500.majtheme: Social protection and risk management,Social dev/gender/inclusion

abstracts.cdata!:
The Earthquake Recovery Project assists
            the Government of Colombia in its efforts to rebuild
            communities following the devastating effects of an
            earthquake that struck the coffee growing region on January
            25, 1999. The project has five components. The first repairs
            and reconstructs partially damaged, totally damaged, and
            structurally damaged housing. It also finances subsidies to
            homeowners and to displaced renters characterized as
            vulnerable (heads of household, the elderly, and those in
            poor health) for new house construction. The second
            component rebuilds and repairs social infrastructure
            (schools, health facilities, and community centers) ad
            provides consultants. The third component rebuilds and
            repairs damaged water and sewerage, power, and transport
            systems as well as it invests environmental protection. The
            fourth component builds the capacity for natural disaster
            management by emphasizing prevention, mitigation, and
            strengthening the management skills of public sector
            agencies. The fifth component finances the costs of
            activities to restore the cohesiveness and studies to
            identify both public and private sector opportunities to
            reactivate the regional economy.
